title: Who dug the trenches in WW1? - Quora

response.answer_text: The vast majority of the trenches and fortifications used in all theaters of the war (Western Front, Eastern Front, Balkan, Mesapotamia, Sinai etc.) were dug by the soldiers themselves. After the war of movement ended and trench warfare began on the Western Front after the First Battle of the Aisne (13 - 28 September, 1914), digging trenches became essential to a soldier’s survival, so most of them became very good at it. As Ernst Junger, one of Germany’s most decorated WWI veterans put it, “the work of maintaining and building fortifications took up most of a soldiers time”, “much of a trench warrior’s day was spent building, repairing and taking turns on watch with occasional breaks for meals and sleep”. Trenches needed constant maintenance. Water had to be constantly pumped out (a daily chore during the fall and spring months), the walls (often 8–12ft tall on either side) had to be reinforced with wood and repaired when they took damage from shelling. Underground bunkers and dugouts had to be built and repaired. The communication trenches that led from the frontline trenches out to the rear also had to be clear of debris. Enemy artillery and mortar fire was constant, even in “quiet” areas of the front, so there was always damage to be repaired and work to be done. Soldiers were trained in digging and basic carpentry but what helped enormously was the fact that many of them were carpenters and builders in civilian life and they were able show their comrades the proper way to get stuff done. Below: German soldiers on watch   Above: Typical front line fortifications As you can see, these structures can get pretty elaborate. These guys were pros at what they did. Anyway sorry if that was a bit long, I hope it helps regardless! Also check out the Great War series on youtube if you want to know more, great stuff. Sources: Junger, Ernst - Storm of Steel The Great War - series on youtube Blueprint for Armageddon - Dan Carlin’s excellent podcast on WWI

As everyon else has said the trenches themselves were initially dug by the first troops who got there, then after that ever unit that manned those positions would both maintain and improve them However the deep shelter dug outs created behind the the Brtish Second line were built by Royal Engineers (in 1917 more troops lived underground in the Ypres Salient than the modern population of Ypres) Additionally the RE designed and commissions mass produced “parts” for trenches to improve them, they provided the (inverted) A Frames that supported duckboards to raisse the feet of soldiers above the water, they produced copies of the screw picket the Germans had for Barbed wires (hammering in a stake in no mans land is not an ideal solution), they provided huge quantities of (empty) sandbags, cut timber and Corrrgated Iron too
